awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Atomic Force Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF MRI acquisition will assist the University of North Dakota (UND) in acquiring an Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) in support of multi-disciplinary research of national interest. The AFM has wide applications among faculty from the science, engineering and medical fields. It will be used to advance materials that can be used for prosthetics and surgical devices and to help develop new biodegradable plastics and pavement materials. It will be used in the development of renewable energy systems and to enhance the capture of carbon. This acquisition directly impacts the careers of the eight primary participants in this proposal, including two female, one Native American, and one first-year faculty member. Users include faculty from the United Tribes Technical College (UTTC).  This proposed research activities will enhance enrollment in STEM disciplines and prepare students for STEM careers.  The instrument will support faculty members from three separate colleges and approximately 25 graduate and 35 undergraduate students, including students who are women and underrepresented minorities.

The Bruker NanoWizard 4XP AFM to be acquired features high-resolution imaging and quantitative nanomechanic capabilities available for use with both top view and inverted optical microscopy, crucial to the co-PIs with life and materials science projects. PeakForce Tapping (PFT) based image acquisition techniques enable control of imaging forces at the pN-level, increasing resolution. Damaging lateral forces are eliminated, enabling high resolution scanning on soft and fragile samples, even in liquid, making it ideal for both materials research and biological samples. The minimum lateral force component of the PFT makes it capable of imaging loosely bound samples on a substrate; therefore, the use of a denaturing fixative or complicated surface chemistry for sample fixation can be avoided. These features allow the team to study the correlation between a polymer’s structure and its physical properties, examine the organic matter in shale plays to determine the mechanisms of expulsion and storage of hydrocarbons, examine how the incorporation of magnetic atoms affects the thermoelectric properties of materials, and to investigate the physical and chemical interactions between specific antibodies and antimicrobial coatings for surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of North Dakota Main Campus

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Acquisition of the Bruker NanoWizard 4XP Atomic Force Microscope  expanded multidisciplinary and innovative research through collaboration among faculty from physics, chemistry, petroleum engineering, mechanical engineering, civil engineering, chemical engineering, and biomedical sciences. Acquisition of this instrument facilitated research activities by removing the obstacle of long-distance travel to conduct research. The biomedical science team started to explore the physical  interactions between a bacterium and non-functionalized AFM cantilever. The team is working on a manuscript and proposal to NIH. The chemistry team is in the process of using the instrument to study thermal conductance of polymers. The physicist have already completed a work on thermal conductance of transition metal chalcogenides. They are currently working on their manuscript.  

 Acquisition of an AFM is directly aligned with UND’s goal of becoming a Carnegie R1 research university. This acquisition directly impacts the eight primary participant’s careers, which includes two female, one Native American, and one first-year faculty member. There is no equipment with similar capabilities in North Dakota or Western Minnesota; therefore, access to this equipment has already initiated collaborations. The team has already have two manuscripts and  two proposals after only having  the instrument for one year.

A diverse and highly motivated science and engineering students (both at grad and undergrad level) have started to work with the instrument. We anticipate the number of students/researchers will increase drastically once the manuscripts are published in peer-review journals. Eventually, we expect that approximately hundereds of undergraduate and graduate students will become familiar with the instrument by either using it directly as part of their coursework, through group projects, or through demonstrations.

Participation of United Tribes Technical College (UTTC) faculty in this proposal helps meet the statewide need of having access to a state-of-the-art AFM system, demontrating a strong preference for engaging faculty and students at tribal-serving colleges in research, leading to STEM disciplines and careers. The engagement is promoted by active research exchanges between the researchers at UND and UTTC and the impactful outreach program designed to interest young Native Americans in STEM fields.  The active involvement of UTTC in outreach activities will allow the team to implement a statewide tribal college initiative fully. 

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2023
Modified by: Nuri Oncel
